s.text: Rall says that Spiegelman, after winning a special Pulitzer in 1992 for his graphic novel Maus , became the de facto spokesman for the sprawling world of "underground comix" and gained the kind of mainstream fame and acceptance most cartoonists only dream of.
A result of living "in a media town where people are too busy to keep track of more than one name per area of expertise."
Even some of his most ardent supporters concede that he's the Quentin Tarantino of cartooning, a guy with one great book in him."

"Winning a Pulitzer Prize for a graphic novel is easy when you've written the only graphic novel Seymour Topping [head of the Pulitzer board] probably ever opened," not to mention that because it was a special citation (and not in the cartooning category), he had no direct competition.

Rall says that Spiegelman, after winning a special Pulitzer in 1992 for his graphic novel Maus , became the de facto spokesman for the sprawling world of "underground comix" and gained the kind of mainstream fame and acceptance most cartoonists only dream of.
